fields.description:
Reviewing Confluence documents is a powerful feature in the Atlassian suite but in its current form it really can only be used by those who can understand wiki text.  There are several improvements that could be made in order to make Confluence document review accessible to Confluence users who use the Rich Text editor.

* Add ability to view diffs/comment on rendered content in addition to diffs in the wiki text.
* Add integration of review functionality already in Confluence with Crucible assuming that both products are present. (linked issue has some ideas but that integration can go deeper).  I'll refrain from designing this but I'll say that the integration in its current form is not incredibly usable by anyone other than a developer due to the complexity of adding items into a review and keeping them up to date.
** Add hooks into Confluence to update active Crucible reviews with the latest published version of a file.  This is possible and done often for other SCM e.g. SVN hooks.
** Add ability to get at Crucible reviews of content from that content in Confluence.  At the very least, active reviews.
fields.summary: Improvements to Confluence document review

The plugin UI should make it clear that the {{Run plugin as user}} setting requires an administrator (maybe also validating the user when saving settings), so as to avoid such problems, or at least log proper error/warning message with some more meaningful exception.

h3. Summary
Horizontal scrollbar just shows up at the end of the file

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Add a large file to the review. The file must contain many lines of code and each line must be long.
# Try to scroll down, and note that the horizontal scrollbar won't show up until the last line of code of the file is reached.

h3. Expected Results
The horizontal scrollbar should be always present if any line of code in the file is long.

h3. Actual Results
The user needs to scroll all the way to the bottom of the file for the horizontal scrollbar to show up. 
This is consistent among different web browsers.

fields.description:
h3. Summary
Whenever a file with a {{utf8}} Perforce filetype containing a BOM header is submitted to depot, the Crucible review with this file says the file is binary. 

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Submit a file with {{utf8}} Perforce filetype containing a BOM header to the depot
# Wait until this file is indexed
# Add this file into a new or existing review
# Try to open this file
# Crucible will say that the file is binary

h3. Expected Results
Crucible should show the file source

h3. Actual Results
Crucible is saying that the file is binary, offering the option to download it.

h3. Perforce versions 
# 2015.2
# 2016.2

h3.Workarounds
* Attach files manually to review works fine — review shows {{utf8}} file as expected.
*OR*
* Change the Perforce filetype to {{text}} with removing BOM header
fields.summary: Perforce: Submitted UTF-8 file with BOM header shows up as binary on review

# Click "Explore Repositories"
# Select {{SVN1}} repository
# Browse to a file and select it
!Screen Shot 2016-09-26 at 5.27.01 PM.png|thumbnail!

# Select {{SVN2}} repository

fields.description:
There are two alternative formats of JDBC url popular amongst Oracle databases:
 * SID format: *{{jdbc:oracle:thin:@localhost:1521:MY_SID}}* 
 * Service name format: *{{jdbc:oracle:thin:@localhost:1521/my_service}}*

FishEye/Crucible suggests SID format in documentation and inside the product.  But For Oracle12c running in Multi-Tenant mode the service name format should be used to allow connections to desired database.

Service format is recommended since Oracle 8, for a long time already, seems like this should be default JDBC url format used by the product.
fields.summary: Suggest different format of JDBC connection string for multitenant Oracle12c

fields.description:
h2. Scenario

1 Create a test repo
2 Added two files (foo.txt and bar.txt)
3 Commit the changes and push to repo
4 Update foo.txt and bar.txt add lines “iteration 1” to both files
5 Create diff and upload the patch “patch_1.diff”
6 Update foo.txt add new line “iteration 2”
7 Revert changes to bar.txt (git checkout previous commit hash)
8 Create diff and upload patch “patch_2.diff”
h2. Result

bar.txt only has one iteration

 
h2. Issue

How can I determine if bar.txt was reverted or just not changed?
h2. Potential Implementation & Resolution 

Since bar.txt is not mentioned in the second patch file, the 2 patch might be compared. A second iteration for bar.txt could then be added with notation signaling if the file was reverted or unchanged.
fields.summary: As a user, it would be helpful if reverted changes were shown/noted in iterations for pre-commit reviews

fields.description:
h3. PROBLEM:

Reviews can only be created on Crucible side. It will be great if there would be an option to create one from JIRA's side when transitioning an issue.

 
h3. SUGGESTION:

I have a workflow in Jira with the steps, in work and in review. As now the issue is moved from in work to in review, I want to create the review ticket in Crucible. In the transitions screen I want to change the assignee. The new assignee is also the person which shall do the review. The assignee will be informed about the new review ticket in Crucible and can start the review. On finishing the review, depending on the review result, the Jira trigger are used to move the Jira issue to the following step in the workflow.
fields.summary: Create Automatic Review in Crucible when Transitioning a JIRA issue

h3. Summary

[Autocomplete] Create Review Select Project search not working with –
 Screen shot show two projects --TWO-TWO-PRO-1- and --TWO-TWO-PRO-2. When starting search with – it only shows TWO-TWO-TWO-PRO-1 and TWO--TWO-TWO-PRO-2.

 # Create Projects in Crucible with the following script:
{code:java}
#!/bin/bash

# August 4, 2016 6:07 AM start

createProject()
{
	a=1
	while [ $a -lt 3 ]
	do
	   echo "Creating project $keys - $a"
	   payload='{
			  "key" : "'"$keys"'-'"$a"'",
			  "name" : "Fisheye and Crucible",

}

for keys in "${key[@]}"; do

done

h3. Workaround

Search without – For instance search with TWO

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition
When creating a review from JIRA, the JIRA issue's description is automatically added to the Review's Objective. 

This will cause a few issues for example, if the JIRA issue's description has a JIRA issue key of another issue, that JIRA issue key will be added to the review objective. When the review is started, it will reflect on both JIRA issues ( even the JIRA issue where the review was not started on ). 

h3. Steps to reproduce
# Created new Agile Scrum JIRA project "TCRUC"
# Created new Crucible project "TESTCR"
# Linked the project in the Application Links of Crucible
# Created a new issue in JIRA (TCRUC-1) and added it to the sprint
# Created a new issue in JIRA (TCRUC-2) with TCRUC-1 mentioned in the description and added it to the sprint
# Perform a commit with both issue keys in the commit message
# Creating a Review for issue TCRUC-1
# Creating a Review for issue TCRUC-2
# The review is added to TCRUC-1 also

h3. Suggested Solution
#  Make it optional to add the JIRA issue description as Crucible objective description when creating the review from JIRA
# Make it optional to create links based on the description

h3. Workaround 
# Manually remove the JIRA issue description from the Crucible Objective
fields.summary: Optional to add JIRA issue description as objective when creating a review from JIRA

fields.description:
With the Crowd server existing in a different domain, Confluence and JIRA are able to overwrite the Crowd {{cookie.domain}} but post 4.0, FishEye/Crucible is not.

Previously, users could specify the {{cookie.domain}} in the FeCru {{config.xml}}.
h5. Scenario

||Application||Domain||Crowd Domain||Overwrite Domain||Results||
|Crowd|.foo.com|N/A|N/A|N/A|
|JIRA|.bar.com|.foo.com|.bar.com|Works|
|Confluence|.bar.com|.foo.com|.bar.com|Works|
|FeCru|.bar.com|.foo.com|.bar.com|Unable to overwrite|
h5. Request

Allow FeCru to overwrite the Crowd cookie.domain setting like JIRA and Confluence are able to do.
fields.summary: Would like to overwrite the Crowd SSO domain configuration

fields.description:
When a review is just opened the page freezes for some period of time. IE10 freezes for a longer amount of time then IE11.
The issue is related to the background work Crucible performs - it loads and renders some files right after the page is loaded. It does the same thing when some file is selected - Crucible loads surrounding files if they were not loaded yet and renders them in the background.
fields.summary: Review page freezes right after opening in IE

fields.description:
Crucible 4.1 introduced "Flexible repository management", which was quite a welcome change. That being said, it does feel incomplete. While it is possible to delegate permission management for repositories, it does not seem to be possible to do so for the projects. It seem that we would need to make all reviews public (including reviews that do not use repository explicitly, but rely on patches instead) to make use of the new feature.

Is this correct or are we missing something? If it is, would it be possible to introduce similar mechanism to both projects and permission schemes?

Or maybe projects could be set so that they copy permissions from their default repository automatically?
fields.summary: Delegating permission management for projects and permission schemes

fields.description:
Just tried to add Changeset Review Coverage plugin from FeCru 4.2.0-SNAPSHOT to JIRA 6.3.4 and it failed.  

Steps to reproduce:
# go to JIRA, manage dashboards, add gadget, add URL
# provide gadet URL pointing your FishEye instance: {{http:/HOSTNAME:PORT/CONTEXT/rest/gadgets/1.0/g/com.atlassian.crucible.plugins.review-coverage-report:recent-changesets/gadget/recent-changesets.xml}}
# submit

I'm getting {{You have specified 'enableReload' for view. This feature requires you to add <UserPref name="refresh" datatype="hidden" default_value="false" /> to <ModulePrefs> in your gadget XML.}} error when I'm expecting gadget to be added.

The problem seems to be caused by invalid GET parameters.  After clicking the "Create Review" button I end up on 
{{http://FECRU/CTX/cru/create?cs=9cfd03c0a98d317f5a84c5a1f34c73821dcfd012&cs=373033fe9ef90be33eea5d8cabea0e445e599193&repo=test}}
URL.
If I rename cs parameters to csid this works as expected, i.e.
{{http://FECRU/CTX/cru/create?csid=9cfd03c0a98d317f5a84c5a1f34c73821dcfd012&csid=373033fe9ef90be33eea5d8cabea0e445e599193&repo=test}}

fields.description:
h3. Summary

Paging for REST API call to "/rest-service/reviews-v1/filter" and "/rest-service/reviews-v1" do not support paging
h3. Steps to Reproduce

Run
{code:java}
curl -X GET -u <username:password> http://localhost:8060/rest-service/reviews-v1/filter?"creator=<username>&limit=2"{code}
h3. Expected Results

Only the first 2 <reviewData> subtrees containing review information are returned.
h3. Actual Results

All <reviewData> subtrees containing review information are returned.
h3. Notes

This also occurs with "/rest-service/reviews-v1". I confirmed that my syntax was correct by testing "/rest-service/repositories-v1?limit=2", and this only returned the first 2 repositories in my list.
h3. Workaround

Retrieve less results when calling this endpoint by making use of the filters available in that endpoint, which can be found [here|https://docs.atlassian.com/fisheye-crucible/4.5.1/wadl/crucible.html#rest-service:reviews-v1:filter:filter].
fields.summary: Paging for REST API call to "/rest-service/reviews-v1/filter" and "/rest-service/reviews-v1" do not support paging

h3. Summary

Whenever a JIRA project has a Security Scheme defined, and a workflow transition has at least one required field, a window is opened in JIRA side so that the required field/s are selected. Among the fields displayed in this window there will be the "Security Level", in which the security levels defined show up along with the "None" option:
!Screen Shot 2016-06-24 at 5.29.12 PM.png|thumbnail!

Whenever this JIRA issue is linked to a Crucible review and it gets clicked, the user is able to transition the JIRA ticket from within Crucible. Whenever the same workflow button clicked in JIRA is clicked in Crucible, a window similar to the one that showed up in JIRA shows up in Crucible, however the "Security Level" field *does not* display the option "None":
!Screen Shot 2016-06-24 at 5.34.09 PM.png|thumbnail!

*Note:* the option "None" is default in JIRA. It was not manually added to the Issue Security Scheme:
!Screen Shot 2016-06-24 at 5.38.48 PM.png|thumbnail!

h3. Environment
* FishEye 4.0.4
* JIRA 6.4.12

h3. Steps to Reproduce
* Explained in the summary

h3. Expected Results
* Show the option "None" in Crucible side

h3. Actual Results
* Only the Issue Security levels manually added to the Issue Security Scheme show up in Crucible.

h3.Workaround
There is no workaround at the moment.
fields.summary: When JIRA project has a security scheme, the option "None" is not displayed in Crucible

fields.description:
This is an umbrella issue to address several usability issues we currently have with adding comments, selecting source code and scrolling the page.

*Problems reported by users:*
 * selecting source code opens the "Add comment" inline dialog; instead of this it should allow to copy code, also from multiple lines (-CRUC-1218-, -CRUC-5890-, -CRUC-7294-*, -CRUC-7751-)
 * current "Alt+drag mouse" for code selection does not work on some Linux distributions (-CRUC-5919-)
 * it should be possible to set the code viewport as active for scrolling purposes (-CRUC-6332-)

*What we need*
 * selection of source code using a mouse without a need to hold Alt (or any other key)
 * selection of multiple source code lines should select code only and not line numbers
 * adding new comments
 * adding new comments covering multiple source lines (also non-continuous ones)
 * single click on source code should do nothing (i.e. just set a focus for scrolling)

*How it could work (proposal)*
 * hovering mouse over left margin with line numbers would show the "<+>" button
 ** clicking on it would show the "Add comment" dialog
 ** pressing Ctrl/Cmd should allow to mark additional lines
 * selecting source lines using a mouse would select source code
 ** it would not pop-up the "Add comment" dialog
 ** it would not select row numbers
 * a single click on the source code would do nothing
 ** it's to give a focus on the frame for scrolling

*Workaround*

A bug fix for copying source is available as a [Copy Source for FishEye and Crucible plugin on Marketplace|https://marketplace.atlassian.com/plugins/com.atlassian.fecru.plugins.fecru-copy-source-plugin/server/overview].
fields.summary: Allow user to easily select one or more lines of source code to copy, to comment on them and to scroll the page

In a review on a repository that has restricted access we disable revision links:

fields.description: If a user creates a comment and then at a later date edits that same comment, we would like to see the change history of that comment.
fields.summary: View change history of individual comments

fields.description: We would like the comments near the code to which they apply, but we don't want them within the code. That is, we don't want to hide the comments and we don't want them at the top of the file. Instead, we want them in a separate, vertical panel alongside the code, that is synchronized with the code. When there are multiple replies to a comment, or multiple comments within a region of code, even collapsing the comments into the faded, reduced height form leaves too little code visible to continue reviewing with visible comments. That means hiding comments and then wondering whether there's already a comment for something just spotted.
fields.summary: Separate window for code comments

fields.description: We would also like mutually exclusive states associated with comments (maybe not also with replies, though they could inherit their state from their parent). We would like to be able to mark a comment as "accepted", meaning that the author will act on the comment without requiring a reply with some "OK" convention. We would like to be able to mark a comment as "done", meaning that the author acted on the comment (though the review may not have been updated to reflect it). Finally, we'd like to be able to mark a comment as "rejected", meaning that the author rejects the reviewer's suggestion. It should be possible to switch among those states freely, and there should be an icon showing the current state.
fields.summary: Separate states for individual comments

fields.description: Currently, when any inline comment is added to a code file, the counter increases.  There does not appear to be a way to determine how many of those comments are "Defects"
fields.summary: Add a way to identify how many "Defects" are in a source file

fields.description: Currently when a comment is marked as a "Defect" the only way to "Close" or "Resolve" a Defect comment is to edit the original comment itself, thus deleting the history.  There should be a mechanism to "Open" and "Close" Defects without overwriting history.
fields.summary: Ability to "close" Defects without edit comment history

h3. Problem Definition
As a product owner I would like to have a clear view of the involvement of developers in the review process by having Crucible exposing pie chart gadget  of the reviews based on Author, Moderator or Reviewers.

 
h3. Workaround 
The information needed is already provided by Crucible through the REST resource https://docs.atlassian.com/fisheye-crucible/latest/wadl/crucible.html#rest-service:reviews-v1
so one possible workaround is to create a gadget that calls the REST endpoint  and formats the information as a pie chart.

More resources on this are available at:
* [Using Atlassian REST APIs in your Gadget|https://developer.atlassian.com/display/GADGETS/Using+Atlassian+REST+APIs+in+your+Gadget]
* [REST Plugin Module|https://developer.atlassian.com/display/DOCS/REST+Plugin+Module]
* [Gadget Developer Documentation|https://developer.atlassian.com/display/GADGETS/Gadget+Developer+Documentation]

fields.description:
h3. Summary
Create a branch from working copy with local modifications shows files as added in the branch while SVN shows them as modified.

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# In your local working copy with modified files create a branch on the SVN server:
{code}
svn copy . https://<Repopath>/branches/local_mod -m "SVN copy using WC->URL"
{code}
# Switch to the branch
{code}
svn switch https://<Repopath>/branches/local_mod
{code}
# Check info for the revision:
{code}
svn log --stop-on-copy -v
------------------------------------------------------------------------
r42 | user.name | 2016-05-04 18:35:14 +0100 (Wed, 04 May 2016) | 1 line
Changed paths:
   A /Project/branches/local_mod (from /Project/trunk:41)
   M /Project/branches/local_mod/README.txt
{code}
# In Crucible create a branch review for the newly created branch.

h3. Expected Results
The file with changes shown as modified.

h3. Actual Results
The file is showed as added:
 !Screen Shot 2016-05-13 at 11.03.17.png|thumbnail! 
 
h3. Notes
The issue was first reproduced using Tortoise SVN  following this process:
# The developer's working copy is on trunk and there are files with local modifications.
# A branch is created in TortoiseSVN from the working copy. This creates the branch and commits the file changes in one action.
# Create a review in Crucible from the branch.
# Modified files are shown as "Added" in Crucible with no diff information.

h3.Workaround
Crucible behaves as expected if a branch is created in the following manner:
# On a working copy with local modifications, using TortoiseSVN create a branch.
# Do not select "Branch from working copy" 
# Select "Switch to branch" then create the branch. At this point the working copy is on the branch and there are still local modifications.
# Commit the local modifications to the branch.
# Create a branch review in Crucible. This correctly shows the files as modified.
fields.summary: Create a branch from working copy with local modifications shows files as added in the branch

fields.description:
After upgrading to Crucible 4.0, the commit section of the blame is no longer colored according to the commit date. This feature is especially helpful when tracking down bugs, development and trying to understand legacy code quickly. 

Previously was color coded (ignore the red circle, I just pulled this from online): 
 !https://confluence.atlassian.com/download/attachments/696518138/crucible-source-createreview.png?version=1&modificationDate=1287473693812&api=v2!

No longer color coded:
 !image-2016-05-12-16-21-55-218.png|thumbnail!
fields.summary: Blame commit is not colored

fields.description:
Hi,

We are using atlassian suite across our organisation of 5 thousand developers. But the crucible is causing a lot of pain. 

We are using crucible with perforce and found the following issues.

Creating review using crucible.py with shelved files fails every time. without deleting shelved files the review creation fails.

Creating review with new files is incorrect. If I add more than one new files to my change list and try to review one file among the added new files is not being shown in review page over portal. Tried multiple times but the issue exists. The uploaded patch contains all the files.

No change list support.

Some times In the portal the file name and file contents are shown different. If I click the File1 in menu it shows File2 contents.

I wish you look into these concerns so it will relive us from the pain else we would look for other alternatives.

Regards,
Siva.
fields.summary: Bunch of errors with crucible + perforce causing big pain to developers.

fields.description:
h3. Summary
Whenever closing a review, if there are other reviews that may need closing, and if they are linked to a JIRA issue, this window comes up:
!Screen Shot 2016-05-09 at 5.29.37 PM.png|thumbnail!

In this screen, before showing the fields that allow transitioning the JIRA issue, the message {{"You are not authorized to make the requested state change"}} gets wrongly displayed for a split second. Two wrong behaviors:
# The user hasn't even tried yet to request the state change in the JIRA issue. He has just clicked the {{Close}} button in the review.
# The JIRA project uses the default permission scheme, so the user logged in is in fact allowed to perform that action.

Debug logging + Network Traffic have been enabled in FishEye and the resulting log file has been attached to this bug report. JIRA logs don't report anything.

h3. Environment
* FishEye / Crucible 4.0.3
* JIRA Software 7.1.6

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Create an application link between FishEye / Crucible and JIRA
# Ensure that the application link uses only OAuth for authentication (and the default OAuth settings)
# Ensure that the OAuth token has been created in both sides, allowing to see details from one instance in the other instance
# Ensure to be using the default project permissions in JIRA side
# Ensure to be using the default permission scheme in Crucible side
# Create two Crucible reviews and link them to the same JIRA issue
# Click {{"Close"}} in any of the reviews
# Notice that, for a split second, the message {{"You are not authorized to make the requested state change"}} comes up, then gets replaced by the JIRA issue fields.

h3. Expected Results
* That message should not be shown before requesting a state change
* That message should be shown only if the user logged in lacks permission to perform the state change in JIRA side

h3. Actual Results
For a split second, the message {{"You are not authorized to make the requested state change"}} comes up, then gets replaced by the JIRA issue fields.
fields.summary: Close Review action quickly shows "You are not authorized to make the requested state change"
Can't search for allowed group in Review Details when "Allowed Review Participants" are specified.

fields.description:
Update the bundled version of java to a version >= 1.8u71 (1.8 update 71), which fixes many security issues (http://www.oracle.com/technetwork/topics/security/cpujan2016-2367955.html#AppendixJAVA).
Included in the security fixes is a fix for CVE-2016-0483 "An out-of-bounds write flaw was found in the JPEG image format decoder in the AWT component in OpenJDK. A specially crafted JPEG image could cause a Java application to crash or, possibly execute arbitrary code. An untrusted Java application or applet could use this flaw to bypass Java sandbox restrictions".


See also: https://blogs.oracle.com/security/entry/security_alert_cve_2016_0603: 8u73 or later is recommended
fields.summary: Update Java version bundled found in the installer to a version >= 1.8u71

fields.description: When adding content to a review using "browse changesets" and then searching for an issue key like "DSP1234", if there are any characters before or after the issue key then the search will not pick up those results. For instance if you have a commit message like "DSP1234: Some files added", this commit message will not show up in the results.
fields.summary: Improve search for Commit Message/ Issue Key when adding content to review

fields.description:
Few reasons:
 * when picking up SQL Server user need to specify version (2005, 2008, 2012 atm), while 2005 is not supported since 3.3 version https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/CRUCIBLE034/End+of+Support+Announcements+for+Crucible
 * 2008 and 2012 settings are effectively identical, no need to distinguish between them
 * simplify the code, remove SQL Server 2005 specific DDLs.  
 * Avoid bugs like CRUC-7702

Change:
 * replace SQL Server versions with single SQL Server.  Determine version in runtime if required, this most likely won't be necessary 
 * allow smooth upgrade for instances where 2008+ instance is used, configured as 2005.  Migrate 2005 schema into 2008?  See CRUC-7702.
fields.summary: Improve SQL Server configuration

fields.description: Crucible's UI seems to be unintuitive and unclear. It's hard to discover features and run reviews, especially for new users. There are issues with searching, scrolling, highlighting code, commenting and lots of other usability-related issues you can tackle with. You can address all those one-by-one or maybe you can consider running total redesign of Crucible.
fields.summary: Redesign Crucible

fields.description:
We often have rejected Smart Commits when people attempt to @username someone who has an unusual or easily misspelled username. Adding an option to create aliases for users which work for Smart Commits would alleviate this frustration.

For example, the user John Doe has the username "john", but most people expect the username to be "jdoe". We would like to be able to configure Smart Commits to work with either @john or @jdoe.
fields.summary: Allow aliases for users in Smart Commits

fields.description:
Backup fails with the error below when using SQL Server 2008 or newer database configured as SQL Server 2005 database. The error is:

{quote}Backing up sql...
1 rows written, 0 of 76 tables completed.
422 rows written, 1 of 76 tables completed.
425 rows written, 3 of 76 tables completed.
426 rows written, 3 of 76 tables completed.
432 rows written, 4 of 76 tables completed.
Error reading database: Cannot encode value for unsupported column type: "datetime" (93) of column .created_date
Backup failed{quote}

As explained in [Migrating to SQL Server|https://confluence.atlassian.com/crucible/migrating-to-sql-server-298977508.html] SQL Server type needs to be specified when setting up database. [SQL Server 2005 support was dropped|https://confluence.atlassian.com/fisheye/supported-platforms-298976955.html] in FishEye/Crucible 3.3 and it will be removed in future versions completely (CRUC-7712).

h3. No workaround
As the SQL Server 2005 and SQL Server 2008+ schema versions differ, there is no easy fix for the problem yet. Changing SQL Server type in Crucible database settings won't help.

h3. Fix
We fixed the issue and will release in the next point release. This will restore the backup capability.

h3. Updating schema
4.0.4 release will workaround the problem of DB using old schema. If you want to update your schema to use correct SQL Server 2012 types, follow these steps:
# Update to 4.0.4 (to be released very soon)
# Update DB setting from "Type=SQLServer 2005" to "Type=SQLServer 2012"; do not update the URL, so no migration will be triggered (click 'Save', not 'Save & Migrate').
# Perform backup
# Restore backup

The restored backup will set up the correct schema for SQL Server 2012.
fields.summary: Backup of misconfigured SQL Server DB fails due to unknown type "datetime" (93)

fields.description:
There are 2 issues related to permission schema. They were grouped together into a single issue, marked with a security label.

h4. Issue 1
User visited in the past Project A.
Also he has visited a review raised in Project A.
FeCru allows him to access those recent items using the menu on top (Project and Reviews respectively, see [^Screenshot-1.png]).
After his access was revoked, he still can see those items in the list of recent items. However after clicking on each of them he gets the error:
* "Not found" for the project (see [^Screenshot-2.png]).
* "Permission denied" for the review (see [^Screenshot-3.png]).

Original issue: [FECRU-6534|https://jira.atlassian.com/browse/FECRU-6534]

h4. Issue 2
User added as a review participant to the review in Project A.
FeCru shown him his reviews in the dashboard page (under "My reviews", see [^Screenshot-4.png]).
After his access was revoked, he still can see the review in the dashboard page. However clicking it leads to "Permission denied" error (see [^Screenshot-3.png]).

Original issue: [FECRU-6535|https://jira.atlassian.com/browse/FECRU-6535]
fields.summary: Permission issues with projects and reviews

fields.description:
h2. Reproducing the problem
Have 6 commits and 2 issue keys with Smart commit. Note that the commits are all done on the same file. Select one of the issue, navigate to the development panel, select the commits list and select "Create Review for all commits".

!screenshot-1.png|thumbnail!

h2. Real Results
From the example in this screenshot, revision 13, 15 and 17 is included in PROJ-4. Upon selecting "Create Review for all commits", Crucible selects revision 13, 14, 15 and 17 instead. Note that all the changes made between revision 13 to 17 is from the same file TEST1. 

!screenshot-2.png|thumbnail!

As a side note, showing previous revisions from the slider usually is provided to diff for individual revisions. So in that case, wouldn't it show all revisions from 13 to 17 as well?

!screenshot-3.png|thumbnail!
fields.summary: Selecting "Create Review for all commits" in JIRA causes unexpected contents/changeset

fields.description:
Currently there's no way of cancelling the review creation after clicking the "Create Review" button. The review is always created. Then in order to get rid of it, it must be abandoned, then deleted afterwards.

The review should only be created in a later step. For example:
After clicking "Create Review", the "Add content to review CR-123" shows up. (Notice that the review already exists at this point)
In this screen, there should be a "Confirm" and a "Cancel" button.

The review should only be really created after clicking the "Confirm" button.
fields.summary: Allow cancelling review creation

fields.description:
*Scenario to reproduce the problem:* 

*Original setup:* 
* Any FishEye/Crucible version prior to 4.0.x, such as 3.10.3 
* The database type does not matter, as soon as it's configured with the correct encoding. For the record, this problem was reproduced in PostgreSQL and MySQL.
* CamelCased group name being used, and user logged in is specified as member of the group. 
* Only this group is granted 'Create' permission in the permission scheme, and the blue 'Create Review' at the top of the screen is shown. 

*After upgrading to 4.0.3:* 
* Blue 'Create Review' button disappears. 
* If JIRA is integrated with Crucible, reviews cannot be created from JIRA issues.

*Workaround:* 
Create lowercased group names, associate the same set of users from the CamelCased groups into the lowercased groups, and grant 'Create' permission only to these groups in the permission scheme. Blue 'Create Review' button should show up, and users should be able to create reviews from JIRA again.
fields.summary: After upgrading to 4.0.3, CamelCased group names stop being recognized

fields.description:
